title: Elise Henle
text:
Elise (Sara) Henle Levi (10 August 1832, <a href="Munich">Munich</a> – 18 August 1892, <a href="Frankfurt">Frankfurt am Main</a>) was a <a href="History%20of%20the%20Jews%20in%20Germany">German Jewish</a> writer, dramatist, and poet. She was the author of numerous <a href="Comedy%20%28drama%29">dramatic comedies</a>, <a href="opera">opera</a> <a href="libretto">libretti</a>, poems, and cookbooks.
Biography.
Elise Henle was born in <a href="Munich">Munich</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bavaria">Bavaria</a> into a wealthy <a href="Jews">Jewish</a> <a href="Court%20Jew">court factor</a> family, the fifth of six children of Therese () and Benedict (Baruch) Henle. Her father had made a name for himself as the author of <a href="Geography">geographical</a> and <a href="Horology">horological</a> <a href="Reference%20work">reference books</a>. He was the son of activist and grandson of Rabbi , and her mother the sister of poet <a href="Henriette%20Ottenheimer">Henriette Ottenheimer</a>. Her brother would become a prominent politician and lawyer of the <a href="House%20of%20Wittelsbach">Bavarian royal family</a>. She was educated at the Aschersche Mädcheninstitut boarding school in Munich.
After her marriage in July 1853 to jewellery manufacturer Leopold Levi, Henle settled in <a href="Esslingen%20am%20Neckar">Esslingen</a>, <a href="W%C3%BCrttemberg">Württemberg</a>, where her house became the <a href="Salon%20%28gathering%29">rendezvous</a> of a distinguished society circle. Later, when her husband's company went <a href="Insolvency">bankrupt</a> in 1881, she moved to Munich to live with her daughter. In 1889 she relocated to her widowed sister's home in <a href="Frankfurt">Frankfurt am Main</a>, where she died three years later. She was buried in the <a href="Old%20Jewish%20Cemetery%2C%20Frankfurt">Frankfurt Jewish Cemetery</a> in a funeral officiated by Rabbi Rudolf Reuben Plaut.
Work.
Elise Henle's first literary publication was the satirical poem "Hut ab!", written in 1867 in response to an <a href="Antisemitism">anti-Semitic</a> statement by a judicial officer. it was followed by the sketch "Beim Volkfest" (1869), the novella "Das Zweite Jägerbataillon" (1869), and the narrative "Die Wacht am Rhein" (1870).
She entered the dramatic field successfully with the <a href="Political%20satire">political</a> <a href="Comedy%20%28drama%29">comedy</a> "Der Zweite September", which was soon followed by the <a href="drama">drama</a> "Percy" (a free adaptation of <a href="Ernst%20Philipp%20Karl%20Lange">Philipp Galen</a>) and the <a href="libretto">libretto</a> of 's romantic-comic opera "Manon, oder Schloß de l'Orme", based on <a href="Abb%C3%A9%20Pr%C3%A9vost">Abbé Prévost</a>'s "Histoire du Chevalier des Grieux et de Manon Lescaut". Her comedies "Durch die Intendanz", "Die Wiener in Stuttgart", "Aus Göthes lustigen Tagen", "Der Erbonkel", and "Liebesqualen" met with marked success in several German and Austrian theatres. The latter was performed at the <a href="Altonaer%20Theater">Stadttheater</a> in <a href="Altona%2C%20Hamburg">Altona</a> on 27 November 1881. She also wrote the text of "Murillo", an opera in three acts with music by , first performed at the <a href="Mannheim%20National%20Theatre">Mannheim National Theatre</a> in 1887.
Near the end of her life, Henle published two popular <a href="Swabian%20German">Swabian German</a> <a href="cookbook">cookbooks</a> in verse, "Guat is's" (1888) and "So mag i's" (1892, reprinted 1988).
